<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_dev_close:
```c
static void metal_linux_dev_close(struct metal_bus *bus,
				  struct metal_device *device)
{
	struct linux_device *ldev = to_linux_device(device);
	struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus);

	ldev->ldrv->dev_close(lbus, ldev);
	metal_list_del(&device->node);
	free(ldev);
}
```
</target_code>

explanation:
No explicit compiler language extensions are present in the provided code fragment. I checked for common non-standard constructs that are explicitly documented as compiler extensions (examples: typeof (GCC), __attribute__, __asm/asm inline assembly, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, __builtin_*, __extension__, __declspec, or other vendor-specific keywords) and none appear in the shown code. The code uses plain C features: function definitions, pointer dereferences, structure definitions, fixed-size arrays (PATH_MAX), standard library free(), and macro invocations (metal_container_of) — none of which by themselves prove use of a language extension.

Note: metal_container_of is used but its definition is not provided here. That macro can be implemented portably (e.g. using offsetof from stddef.h) or may use compiler-specific typeof in some implementations. Because the macro definition is not present in the supplied snippets, I did not flag the call sites as definite uses of a language extension. If you want a definitive determination, provide the definition of metal_container_of (and any other macros used) so it can be inspected for compiler-specific extensions.
